title: TomPegden published Export advice at Radisson Blu Hotel, East Midlands Airport
text:
Export advice at Radisson Blu Hotel, East Midlands Airport By TomPegden | Posted: February 28, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Radisson Blu Hotel, next to East Midlands Airport Export advice at Radisson Blu Hotel, East Midlands Airport X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
Global business opportunities in the years leading up to, during and post-Brexit will be high on the agenda at an export seminar in Leicestershire next month. 
The Leicester Mercury has teamed up with the Department of International Trade to present Exporting: Is It For You? on Thursday, March 23. 
It coincides with a Government campaign to urge more businesses to make 2017 the year of exporting by seeking new markets and seizing on the demand for British goods and services. 
Exports contribute more than £500 billion to GDP and the Government is putting a renewed focus on international trade. 
The Leicestershire event – which takes place at the Radisson Blu Hotel, next to East Midlands Airport – is aimed at businesses which want to grow and develop into international export. 
Read more: Jones Bootmaker put up for sale two years after it was sold to US firm 
Experts will be on hand to offer export advice on how to maximise sales and offer techniques on attracting new clients overseas. 
Nikki Kandola, regional events manager at Leicester Mercury parent company Trinity Mirror, said: "The exporting seminar is a great opportunity for like-minded businesses to network and learn techniques on how to grow revenue. 
Read more: Record sales and CarShop deal make Sytner county's biggest business 
"Exporting is such a huge topic and a seminar like this a great way for businesses of all sizes to receive some free expert advice and tips." 
It comes as the Department for International Trade is developing almost 200 high value exporting campaigns to target markets and sectors and help UK companies make their mark abroad. 
International Trade Secretary, Dr Liam Fox, said he wanted to encourage businesses big and small, up and down the country, to take advantage. 
He said: "From technology in India to aerospace in the USA there's no shortage of demand and UK businesses have the knowledge, skills and expertise to truly add value and make the UK a partner of choice. 
"We are world-leaders in many sectors such as financial services and technology. 
"My department has already identified more than 50 countries that could benefit from British expertise and we are continuing work on exploring more export opportunities with other nations. 
"We have a real opportunity to build on this country's wide range of successful exports, reach out to new markets and help more businesses achieve their exporting potential." 
The seminar will begin at 8.30am and finish no later than 11.30am and breakfast will be provided.
